awd_titl_txt: Improving Problem-based Learning through Personalized Online Instruction that Promotes Student Engagement, Motivation, and Self-efficacy
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the NSF Improving Undergraduate STEM Education Program: Education and Human Resources (IUSE: EHR), this project aims to serve the national interest by developing instructional support tailored to the needs of individual undergraduate students in introductory engineering courses. In collaboration with Mercy College (a Hispanic Serving Institution), Rowan University will examine the efficacy of combining intelligent tutoring with narrative problem-based simulations to enhance student comprehension of key concepts in electrical and computer engineering. The long-term objective of the project is to develop a digital model of student-teacher classroom interactions that address students' specific difficulties, thereby improving problem-based learning instructional practices. 

The project aims to personalize online problem-based learning through incorporation of intelligent, online  tutoring.  In addition, the project plans to develop an artificial intelligence-based facial recognition system to capture fluctuations in learner emotions (e.g., confusion; calm; confidence) during the learning process. The project will conduct research to explore the extent to which personalized, online problem-based learning enhances students' learning and problem-solving ability.  Results of this research will provide further insights about the effectiveness of problem-based learning, metacognition, and narrative simulations in undergraduate education. The theoretical framework that guides the work incorporates social cognitive learning theory. A comprehensive and proactive plan for disseminating the results includes seminars, publications, web and social networking presence, online educator support, and K-12 outreach. The NSF IUSE: EHR Program supports research and development projects to improve the effectiveness of STEM education for all students. Through the Engaged Student Learning track, the IUSE program supports the creation, exploration, and implementation of promising practices and tools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project (https://users.rowan.edu/~tang/#/gridlock) results in a personalized instructional game system that has been developed and integrated into the curricula at Electrical and Computer Engineering of Rowan and Computer Science of Mercy College. This system contains Gridlock, a virtual reality (VR) serious game for teaching digital logic design, along with several key back-end components to offer students with tailored scaffolding during gameplay. Extensive testing was conducted throughout the project cycle to evaluate various aspects of both the game and personalized assistance system, as well as students’ experiences using the game and system as auxiliary classroom tools to boost their learning. The findings from this project prove the effectiveness of personalized game-based learning as a way to improve students’ classroom experiences and learning, while simultaneously providing the research community as a whole with numerous insights, completed studies, and finalized systems for personalized assistance to help advance the field. Research outcomes have been published in over 20 conference and journal articles, with several nominated for best paper awards, and one receiving the Best Student Paper award. The Principal Investigator has actively disseminated the project results through twelve invited talks, including five keynote speeches.

Throughout the project, undergraduate students from Rowan University participated in game development and system implementation each semester through the engineering clinic program, with several graduate students spearheading development and managing undergraduate work. The system for personalized assistance has been published to the research community, and the serious game Gridlock has been made available for free to any students or teachers who wish to apply it in their own classrooms or own education. Throughout our in-classroom testing, numerous students have also expressed interest in the project itself, expanding their idea of what education can be and bolstering their interest in STEM fields.

The development blends informal and formal learning, enhancing, but more importantly enabling life-long science and engineering discovery that might not have been possible in the past. The award has made a big impact on the targeted engineering students in the way that they: (a) develop enhanced strategic thinking and a deeper understanding of engineering concepts; (b) apply these concepts to real-world scenarios; and (c) increase their motivation and engagement with learning. Additionally, the funding has also facilitated advancements in personalization techniques.

 


Last Modified: 11/19/2024
Modified by: Ying Tang
